dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news out of the Supreme Court, huh? Like, something we’ve been waiting on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big news out of the Supreme Court, huh? Like, something we've been waiting on.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for sure. They finally, uh, cleared the way for that big antitrust suit against Apple's App Store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for sure. They finally, uh, cleared the way for that big antitrust suit against Apple's App Store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? I mean, it felt like this was always coming, but now it's actually happening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I mean, it felt like this was always coming, but now it's actually happening.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, for anyone, um, maybe not totally up to speed, what's the core issue here? Is it that "Apple Tax" everybody talks about?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, for anyone, um, maybe not totally up to speed, what's the core issue here? Is it that Apple Tax everybody talks about?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's all about that 30% commission Apple takes, or the 15% after the first year, on subscriptions and in-app purchases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's all about that thirty percent commission Apple takes, or the fifteen percent after the first year, on subscriptions and in-app purchases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's what Spotify and, like, Netflix have been so vocal about for ages.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's what Spotify and, like, Netflix have been so vocal about for ages.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, definitely. I mean, Daniel Ek from Spotify, he's called it, uh, anti-competitive, saying it stifles innovation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, definitely. I mean, Daniel Ek from Spotify, he's called it, uh, anti-competitive, saying it stifles innovation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experience—essentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And Apple's argument against all this? They always have a strong defense, don't they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Apple's argument against all this? They always have a strong defense, don't they?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they say developers actually set their own prices, for one. And, um, the vast majority of apps on the App Store are free.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they say developers actually set their own prices, for one. And, um, the vast majority of apps on the App Store are free.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Developers set the price they want to charge for their app and Apple has no role in that. The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] But they still make a ton of money from those free ones, right? Through ads or other services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they still make a ton of money from those free ones, right? Through ads or other services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And their point is, they only take a cut if developers choose to sell digital services through the App Store itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And their point is, they only take a cut if developers choose to sell digital services through the App Store itself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The only instance where Apple shares in revenue is if the developer chooses to sell digital services through the App Store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, this isn't the first time Apple's faced this kind of challenge, though, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, this isn't the first time Apple's faced this kind of challenge, though, is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, like, there was a suit back in 2011 where Apple actually won.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, like, there was a suit back in twenty eleven where Apple actually won.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011... Apple sought to have the suit tossed out... Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments... The case will continue through the courts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, on a technicality, I think I remember. Something about consumers not having the legal standing to sue?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, on a technicality, I think I remember. Something about consumers not having the legal standing to sue?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple sought to have the suit tossed out, arguing the iPhone owners lacked the legal standing to bring the suit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. They cited this old "Illinois Brick" case. But, uh, this new antitrust suit? It's definitely moving forward now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. They cited this old Illinois Brick case. But, uh, this new antitrust suit? It's definitely moving forward now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent, the Illinois Brick case involving pricing of concrete masonry blocks, to argue that consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price (in this case, the app developers). ... The case will continue through the courts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, big implications then, for the whole digital retail landscape, not just Apple.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big implications then, for the whole digital retail landscape, not just Apple.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The outcome could have implications for any digital retailer, say consumer advocates. ... That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Consumer advocates are saying it could totally change how, um, platforms like this operate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Consumer advocates are saying it could totally change how, um, platforms like this operate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could mean theres going to be a variety of new things the platforms have to consider, says John Bergmayer, an attorney for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Fascinating. And Apple's still confident they'll prevail, of course.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fascinating. And Apple's still confident they'll prevail, of course.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple issued a statement, saying its confident that it will prevail in court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Always are. But, uh, this time it feels a bit different.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Always are. But, uh, this time it feels a bit different.
